repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Casamance Emergency
            Reconstruction Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Casamance Emergency
            Reconstruction Support Project for Senegal were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Lessons learned include: the
            Casamance experience confirms that while a demobilization
            and reintegration program is important it needs to be
            complemented with broader development and social
            mobilization efforts that can sustain peace. Building trust,
            rebuilding social capital, and finding areas of common
            ground between all stakeholders in parallel with formal
            negotiations are key to achieving sustainable results in
            fragile conditions. Project implementation shows that in
            post conflict situations it is essential to first identify
            and then address the causes of conflict. Before the Mid-term
            Review (MTR) restructuring, it became clear that the peace
            benefits from infrastructure rehabilitation were significant
            despite the interruption in the negotiations and further
            postponement of demobilization. It is clear from the
            experience of the project that peace cannot be achieved
            through negotiations alone, but requires a minimal
            functional basic socio economic infrastructure. The project
            unit in Ziguinchor realized that it had to obtain agreements
            from all stakeholders, as well as from local MFDC (Mouvement
            des Forces Democratiques de la Casamance - rebellion
            movement in Casamance) representatives, on which
            infrastructure to rehabilitate. The implementation unit in
            Ziguinchor was only able to attract staff from the region
            when it was established. Staff from other parts of Senegal
            was not inclined to come and or bring their families in view
            of the uncertain security situation prevailing at the start
            of the project.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Casamance Emergency
            Reconstruction Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Casamance Emergency Reconstruction
            Support Project aims to support the Government of Senegal
            in: (a) facilitating a speedy restoration in Casamance of a
            productive economic and social environment similar to that
            existing in the rest of Senegal; and (b) laying the
            groundwork for sustainable long-term development in the
            region, while fully respecting its specificities. To achieve
            its objectives, the project will have three components: (1)
            demobilization and reinsertion of combatants and other
            conflict victims; (2) infrastructure reconstruction and
            rehabilitation; and (3) technical support for the
            preparation o f a long-term development program. The
            projects support for long-term development program
            preparation and cross-cutting issues including monitoring
            and evaluation, conflict warning and prevention, social
            mobilization, social and environmental activities, project
            management. This component aimed at funding studies
            (hydraulics, land tenure, transport, tourism, private sector
            development, environmental and natural resources), and
            salaries, equipment, and capacity building of the project
            coordinating unit. The project improve key infrastructure in
            education, health, transport, including the electrification
            of rural medical centers. The project increase school gross
            enrollment rate to the level it was before the conflict (93
            percent) and increases the use of health facilities by 40
            percent. Number of communities connected to the core road
            network (all-weather roads). The project results will allow
            gauging the effectiveness of the advocacy strategy in the
            peace process and the subsequent effective demobilization of
            rebels. Gauge the effectiveness of the strategy to improve
            not only the access to better social services, but also to
            promote the peace process as a whole.

5540700.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Casamance Emergency
            Reconstruction Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Casamance Emergency Reconstruction
            Support Project aims to support the Government of Senegal
            in: (a) facilitating a speedy restoration in Casamance of a
            productive economic and social environment similar to that
            existing in the rest of Senegal; and (b) laying the
            groundwork for sustainable long-term development in the
            region, while fully respecting its specificities. To achieve
            its objectives, the project will have three components: (1)
            demobilization and reinsertion of combatants and other
            conflict victims; (2) infrastructure reconstruction and
            rehabilitation; and (3) technical support for the
            preparation o f a long-term development program. In
            addition, the National Agency for the Recovery o f Social
            and Economic Activities in Casamance (ANRAC) will directly
            implement other cross-cutting activities, such as
            instituting a management information system. The project
            will benefit Senegal as a whole and the Casamance region in
            particular. All ex-combatants and their families will be
            offered opportunities to resume normal civilian lives with
            appropriate economic activities. Approximately 30,000
            displaced persons will be supported in their return to
            normal life in their original homes. After project
            completion, Casamance is expected to be an exporter of
            agricultural products abroad and a supplier to the local
            Senegalese market. Significant foreign direct investment in
            the tourism sector should also occur once regional stability
            is secured. External risks to the project include: 1. A
            full-scale rebellion because of disagreements between the
            Rebellion Movement in Casamance (MFDC) and the Government;
            and repeated attacks staged by gangs of former combatants.
            Project risks comprise the following: 1) Poor coordination
            among the various efforts taking place in Casamance; 2) Lack
            of collaboration/trust between the administration and the
            beneficiaries.; 3) Slowness of implementation and
            disbursement; and 4) Inability of displaced persons to
            return to their original homes.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal -Casamance Emergency Reconstruction
            Support Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is a regional environmental
            assessment for the Senegal Casamance Emergency
            Reconstruction Support Project, which identifies the
            environmental and social potential of the Casamance, in
            terms of land and water resources, in biodiversity and in
            marine resources, and presents a regional analysis of the
            degradation of these natural resources. The analysis further
            demonstrates the detrimental impact of currently ongoing,
            resource degradation and its socioeconomic consequence; and
            identifies all pertinent positive and negative impacts
            expected of program interventions. Project interventions
            comprise demining, demobilization, community development,
            and reconstruction. Of the four, the component supporting
            reconstruction and rehabilitation of non-community
            infrastructures may have major negative impacts-although
            this component could have a distinct positive impact when
            correcting existing infrastructure problems. General risks
            concern the overexploitation of forest resources; accidents
            connected with demining; conflicts over land use, especially
            between farmers and herders, and newcomers and residents;
            social and political discrimination; the spread of sexually
            transmitted diseases-particularly HIV/AIDS; disappearing
            species and the loss of habitats; flooded lands;
            agro-chemical pollution of water and soil from pesticides;
            soil salinity, sedimentation, and erosion; increase of
            water-borne illnesses; air pollution caused by dust from
            solid and liquid waste disposal; transformation and
            destruction of coastal areas and mangrove areas because of
            shrimp production;  Mitigation measures will include
            rehabilitating degraded natural habitats; construction and
            rehabilitation of anti-salinity dikes; involving the
            population in improving land management; and institutional
            measures that improve knowledge of biodiversity and
            environmental management, evaluate natural resources,
            regulate their uses, and put in place measures for their
            conservation; and training, information, and awareness
            building measures. Also recommended is supplementary project
            financing from the GEF Operational Program on sustainable
            land management in order to further improve the land
            resource base of the Casamance.

repnme.cdata!:
Senegal - Casamance Emergency
            Reconstruction Support Project : resettlement framework

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement framework discusses
            the criteria and the means to be used in assessing losses to
            project affected persons and compensating them equitably in
            a transparent procedure. Affected persons in this instance
            are individuals, households, or villages subject to
            involuntary land expropriation as a result of the project,
            particularly the component supporting infrastructure
            rehabilitation, who have lost land or property, goods or
            access to those goods, sources of income or the means of
            subsistence, or those persons displaced from protected areas
            losing access to natural resources, whether or not they are
            owners by law. The affected populations will participate in
            the negotiations determining their reintegration and
            recovery of losses. In general, persons with land rights
            receive compensation for land loss--at market value--as well
            as other support, while occupants, persons without legally
            recognized land rights will receive housing at replacement
            value along with relocation aid and other support.
            Households will be given the option of receiving
            compensation in kind for goods that are damaged or
            destroyed. Vulnerable groups such as women, children, the
            elderly, the sickly, single females engaged in agricultural
            production or female heads of household, etc. will be
            identified through socioeconomic studies. These studies will
            also conduct institutional studies and elaborate systems for
            monitoring and evaluation.
